abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project is rated
            satisfactory, and sustainability is high. The key lessons
            address institutional, technical/social, and operational
            issues as follows: 1) Institutionally, the central
            government needs to play a leading role to initiate a
            national response, in the face of a new public health
            threat, namely HIV/AIDS, inadequately recognized by society,
            particularly when institutional capacity is limited. It is
            suggested that following the initial program implementation,
            decentralization to states, and municipal corporations,
            should take place, to ensure appropriate local responses to
            epidemiological patterns, institutional capacities, and
            commitment to the program. The government should establish
            partnerships across sectors, with NGOs, and include the
            participation of the private sector. 2) Technically and
            socially, there is a need to create effective coverage to
            plan program interventions, through public information,
            enabling policy adjustments, and behavior changes. Improved
            health methods should be ensured, through broader blood
            banking systems, rather than the HIV testing alone, and,
            epidemic differentials should be considered. Financial
            management systems should be strengthened to maintain
            epidemiological quality. 3) Operationally, the development
            of a computerized financial management system would
            alleviate financial, and accounting practices, and
            forecasting systems could be included.
